'''''Agaricus subrufescens''''' ([[Synonym (biology)|syn.]] ''Agaricus blazei'', ''Agaricus brasiliensis'' or ''Agaricus rufotegulis'') is a species of [[mushroom]], commonly known as '''almond mushroom''', '''mushroom of the sun''', '''God's mushroom''', '''mushroom of life''', '''royal sun agaricus''', '''''jisongrong''''', or '''''himematsutake''''' (Chinese: {{lang|zh|巴西蘑菇}}, Japanese: {{lang|ja|姫まつたけ}}, "princess [[matsutake]]") and by a number of other names. ''Agaricus subrufescens'' is [[edible mushroom|edible]], with a somewhat sweet taste and fragrance of [[almond]]s.

==Taxonomy==
''Agaricus subrufescens'' was first described by the American botanist [[Charles Horton Peck]] in 1893.<ref>{{Cite journal|author= Peck CH|year=1893 |title=Report of the Botanist (1892)|journal=Annual Report on the New York State Museum of Natural History |volume= 46|pages=85–149}}</ref> During the late 19th and early 20th centuries, it was cultivated for the table in the eastern United States.<ref name="pmid16389952">{{Cite journal|pmid=16389952 |doi=10.3852/mycologia.97.1.12 |year=2005 |last1=Kerrigan |first1=RW |title=Agaricus subrufescens, a cultivated edible and medicinal mushroom, and its synonyms |volume=97 |issue=1 |pages=12–24 |journal=Mycologia}}</ref> It was discovered again in Brazil during the 1970s, and misidentified as ''Agaricus blazei'' Murrill, a species originally described from Florida. It was soon marketed for its purported medicinal properties under various names, including ABM (for ''Agaricus blazei'' Murrill), ''cogumelo do sol'' (mushroom of the sun), ''cogumelo de Deus'' (mushroom of God), ''cogumelo de vida'' (mushroom of life), ''himematsutake'', royal sun agaricus, ''Mandelpilz'', and almond mushroom.

In 2002, Didukh and Wasser correctly rejected the name ''A. blazei'' for this species, but unfortunately called the Brazilian fungus ''A. brasiliensis'',<ref name="didukh_2002">{{Cite journal|first1=Solomon P. |last1=Wasser |first2=Marina Ya. |last2=Didukh |first3=Maria Angela L. |last3=de Amazonas |first4=Eviatar |last4=Nevo |first5=Paul |last5=Stamets |first6=Augusto F. |last6=da Eira |year=2002 |title=Is a Widely Cultivated Culinary-Medicinal Royal Sun Agaricus (the Himematsutake Mushroom) Indeed ''Agaricus blazei'' Murrill? |journal=International Journal of Medicinal Mushrooms |volume=4 |issue=4 |pages=267–290 |oclc=39977461 |doi=10.1615/intjmedmushr.v4.i4.10}}</ref> a name that had already been used for a different species, ''[[Agaricus brasiliensis]]'' Fr. (1830). Richard Kerrigan undertook genetic and interfertility testing on several fungal strains,<ref name="pmid16389952"/> and showed that samples of the Brazilian strains called ''A. blazei'' and ''A. brasiliensis'' were genetically similar to, and interfertile with, North American populations of ''Agaricus subrufescens''. These tests also found European samples called ''A. rufotegulis'' to be of the same species. Because ''A. subrufescens'' is the oldest name, it has [[Taxonomy (biology)|taxonomical]] priority.

==Description==
[[File:Agaricus subrufescens annulus.jpg|thumb|right|The floccose stipe and annulus of ''A. subrufescens'']]

The [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] is initially hemispherical, later becoming convex, with a diameter of {{convert|5|to|18|cm|in|abbr=on}}.<ref name=Murrill1922>{{Cite journal|doi=10.2307/3753642 |journal=Mycologia |year=1922 |volume=14 |issue=4 |title=Dark-Spored Agarics: III. Agaricus |last=Murrill |first=W. A. |pages=200–221 |jstor=3753642}}</ref> The cap surface is covered with silk-like fibers, although in maturity it develops small scales (squamulose). The color of the cap may range from white to grayish or dull reddish brown; the cap margin typically splits with age. The [[trama (mycology)|flesh]] of ''A. subrufescens'' is white, and has the taste of "green nuts", with the odor of almonds.<ref name=Murrill1922 /> The [[lamellae (mycology)|gills]] are not attached to the stalk (free), narrow, and crowded closely together. They start out whitish in color, then later pinkish and finally black-brown as the spores mature. [[Spore]]s are ellipsoid, smooth, dark purplish-brown when viewed microscopically, with dimensions of 6–7.5 by 4–5 [[micrometre|μm]]. The [[stipe (mycology)|stipe]] is {{convert|6|to|15|cm|in|abbr=on}} by {{convert|1|to|1.5|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} thick, and bulbous at the base. Initially solid, the stipe becomes hollow with age; it is cottony (floccose) to scaly towards the base.<ref name=Murrill1922 /> The [[Annulus (mycology)|annulus]] is abundant and double-layered; it is bent downwards towards the stem, smooth and whitish on the upper side, and covered with cottony scales on the lower side.

''Agaricus subrufescens'' is edible, with a somewhat sweet taste and [[almond]] [[aroma]] resulting from [[benzaldehyde]], [[benzyl alcohol]], [[benzonitrile]], and [[methyl benzoate]].<ref name="Chen_1984">{{Cite journal|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2621.1984.tb10433.x |title=Volatile Components of Mushroom (Agaricus subrufecens) |year=1984 |last1=Chen |first1=CHU-CHIN |last2=Wu |journal=Journal of Food Science |volume=49 |pages=1208–1209 |first2=Chung-MAY|issue=4}}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
''Agaricus subrufescens'' forms fruit bodies singly or in clusters in leaf litter in rich soil, often in domestic habitats.<ref name="isbn0-472-85599-9">{{Cite book|author=Smith, Alexander Hanchett |title=A Field Guide to Western Mushrooms |publisher=University of Michigan Press |location=Ann Arbor, Mich |year=1975 |page=228 |isbn=978-0-472-85599-5}}{{Page needed|date=August 2010}}</ref> Originally described from the northeastern United States and Canada, it has been found growing in California, Hawaii, Great Britain, the Netherlands, Taiwan, Philippines, Australia and Brazil.<ref name="pmid16389952"/>

==Uses and safety concerns==
Used in [[traditional medicine|traditional]] and [[alternative medicine]] for its supposed [[anti-cancer]] effects, ''Agaricus'' mushrooms have not been assessed by sufficient high-quality [[clinical research]] to define safety and biological properties upon consumption as a food, [[dietary supplement]], or [[drug]].<ref name="mskcc">{{cite web |title=Agaricus |url=https://www.mskcc.org/cancer-care/integrative-medicine/herbs/agaricus#msk_professional |publisher=Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center |accessdate=21 November 2018 |date=2018}}</ref> Preliminary research indicates ''Agaricus'' products may have [[toxicity|toxic]] effects on [[liver]] function by inhibition of [[Cytochrome P450|P450 enzyme]]s, especially in people with [[ovarian cancer]],<ref name=mskcc/><ref name="sweet">{{cite journal |pmc=4613776|year=2013|last1=Sweet|first1=E. S.|title=Adverse events associated with complementary and alternative medicine use in ovarian cancer patients|journal=Integrative Cancer Therapies|volume=12|issue=6|pages=508–516|last2=Standish|first2=L. J.|last3=Goff|first3=B.|last4=Andersen|first4=M. R.|pmid=23625025|doi=10.1177/1534735413485815}}</ref> and may cause [[allergic reaction]]s.<ref name=mskcc/> The US [[Food and Drug Administration]] has issued [[FDA warning letter|warning letters]] to companies marketing ''Agaricus'' supplement products with unproven [[health claim]]s of providing benefits to the [[immune system]].<ref>{{cite web |author1=Ronald Pace |title=Warning letter: C P Health Products Inc |url=https://www.fda.gov/ICECI/EnforcementActions/WarningLetters/2014/ucm405674.htm |publisher=Inspections, Compliance, Enforcement, and Criminal Investigations, US Food and Drug Administration |accessdate=21 November 2018 |date=15 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author1=LaTonya M. Mitchell |title=Warning letter: EnerHealth Botanicals, LLC |url=https://www.fda.gov/ICECI/EnforcementActions/WarningLetters/ucm410131 |publisher=Inspections, Compliance, Enforcement, and Criminal Investigations, US Food and Drug Administration |accessdate=21 November 2018 |date=8 August 2014}}</ref>
